STORM

STORytellying and Metaphors Ontology

Learn More

About

This project was carried out by Ioanna Antonatou, Milena Corbellini and Maria Chiara Gollini, for the course of Knowledge Representation and Extraction offered by the MA Digital Humanities and Digital Knowledge of the University of Bologna. The project aims at exploring the relationship between metaphors and storytellying, based on our hypothesis that several narrative devices may be reflected in individual metaphors. We demonstrate the connections we extracted in the ontology STORM, which we created for the purposes of this project.

The STORM Ontology

The STORM (STOrytelling and Metaphors) ontology examines metaphors and their connections to storytelling theories by influential scholars. More specifically, the ontology focuses on metaphors found in Shakespearean works and the ways in which they reflect storytelling aspects. With this project we attempt to demonstrate that metaphors do not only throw light on the conscious or subconscious narrative methods employed by the author, but that they may also provide insight into the main ideas of a story. Ultimately, we argue that the topic of a story may be extracted by the metaphors found in the work.

Steps

The ontology derives data from two works by Shakespeare, a comedy (As you Like It) and a tragedy (Macbeth). We extracted the metaphors from the two plays and analyzed them using classes and object properties concerning aspects of metaphors themselves and storytellying. We examined the connections between narration and the use of metaphors and drew conclusions about the extent of their relationship in the two genres.

Some Numbers

  • 14 imported classes
  • 91 Classes
  • 54 Object properties
  • 15 Data properties
  • 2449 Axiooms
  • 3 Authors

The team

Ioanna Antonatou
Her academic interests include linguistics, storytelling and user experience.
Milena Corbellini
Her academic interests include linguistics, storytelling, philology and editing.

Her academic interests include knowledge organization, textual mining and 3D modeling.
